bug.description:
I am following this tutorial <denchmark-link:http://www.bitfusion.io/2016/08/31/training-a-bird-classifier-with-tensorflow-and-tflearn/>http://www.bitfusion.io/2016/08/31/training-a-bird-classifier-with-tensorflow-and-tflearn/</denchmark-link> I assume that training was done but the system was restarted so I can't verify if the 100 epochs were done. Can you please suggest fixes? Is this a tflearn and tensorflow version mismatch? Can you try changing this line in your code: model.load("bird-classifier.tfl.ckpt-50912") ...to the following: model.load("./bird-classifier.tfl.ckpt-50912") ...and let us know if that works?
I had the identical issue with r1.0.0 and adding the "./" in front of the file name resolved the issue for me.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/mrry>@mrry</denchmark-link> : Thanks for your help! Adding a did solve the problem. Although a trivial solution, it took me a long time to figure this out. Also, don't you think models should be loaded even without that? Many of the existing tensorflow models available on github and elsewhere simply specify adding a without a to load an existing checkpoint.
Yes, I do think so :). <denchmark-link:https://github.com/rohan100jain>@rohan100jain</denchmark-link> fixed this bug recently, so it should work as expected if you use a nightly build.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/Raghu-kapur>@Raghu-kapur</denchmark-link> your error-message reads: ... then nothing. This sounds like there is a missing parameter. Did you provide the option --trained_checkpoint_prefix with the prefix als value for your model for the export_inference_graph.py script? <denchmark-link:https://github.com/redbullpeter>@redbullpeter</denchmark-link> it looks like providing a full path to the model also works for the option:
i don't know why but sometimes we have to provide absolute path for the model ckpt
Restoring a checkpoint failed for me when the path of the checkpoint contained symbols like [ or ,. Removing these characters solved the error.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/gcucurull>@gcucurull</denchmark-link> that is not an issue of tensorflow/object-detection, but the standard behaviour of certain operating systems. Brackets, comma, spaces etc. should be escaped if provided to any program (at least in the context of linux or MacOS).
I copied the model i used an point to older directory in python path.. Maybe you done same thing
I also encountered this problem, solved with an absolute address, the relative address tensorflow is not recognized.
